content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Locate a round-trip flight from Buenos Aires to Beijing, leaving on May 28, 2026, and returning on June 3, 2026, check out one of the options and tell me if the airline for my return flight is the same as my departure flight.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to set the departure city to Buenos Aires and the destination to Beijing. The current "Where from?" field shows "Toronto." The first step will be to change the departure city to Buenos Aires.
Action: Type [13]; Buenos Aires
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure city is now set to Buenos Aires. Next, I need to enter the destination city, Beijing, in the "Where to?" field to proceed with the flight search.
Action: Type [14]; Beijing
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure and destination cities are correctly filled in as Buenos Aires and Beijing. The next step is to select the departure date (May 28, 2026).
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current view only shows September and October, but the desired departure date is May 28, 2026. I need to scroll forward through the calendar months to reach May 2026.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying October and November. May 2026 is still several months ahead, so I need to continue clicking "Next" to reach May 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.37
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is displaying November and December but I need to reach May 2026. I need to keep clicking "Next" to advance several more months.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.38
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now displaying December and January 2026. May 2026 is still several months ahead, so I need to keep clicking the "Next" button to advance to May 2026.
Action: Click [76]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now displaying January and February 2026. I still need to advance to May 2026, so I need to continue clicking "Next."
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.41
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar view is currently on February and March 2026. I need to continue advancing forward to reach May 2026 for the desired departure date.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.43
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently showing March and April 2026. I still need to reach May 2026, so I should continue to the next months.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar finally shows May 2026, which is needed for the departure date (May 28, 2026). I should select May 28, represented by [68], as the departure date.
Action: Click [68]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure date (May 26) is selected, but the required date for departure is May 28, 2026. I need to select May 28, which is marked by [73] in the calendar for May 2026.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Both the departure date (May 28, 2026) and a return date are needed for a round-trip, but currently, May 28 is selected as the return date and May 26 is the departure. I need to set the return for after the departure (June 3, 2026). I need to move to June 2026 in the calendar.
Action: Click [80]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now displaying June 2026. I need to select June 3, 2026, as the return date, which corresponds to element [53]. This will set the proper return date for the round-trip search.
Action: Click [53]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dates are incorrectly set to both departing and returning on June 5. I need to set May 28, 2026 as the departure (from May calendar) and June 3, 2026 as the return (from June calendar). First, select May 28 as the departure date.
Action: Click [44]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.82
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: May 28, 2026 is now selected as the departure date. To finish setting the correct return date, I need to choose June 3, 2026, which is represented by [51] in the June 2026 calendar.
Action: Click [51]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The correct dates are set: departure on May 28, 2026, and return on June 3, 2026. I now need to confirm these dates and continue to see the available flight options by clicking "Done."
Action: Click [83]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.9

Action: Click [22]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.92

I need to check the details of one of the flight options to compare the airline for the departure and return flights. Thought: The expanded flight details section appears to only show information about the departing flight (May 28) and does not display the return flight details. To answer the task, I need to see if the return flight airline matches the departure. I should scroll down to look for additional details, especially about the return segment.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down

Completion: 0.96
